title: Smallest Inverse Sum of Divisors
text:
First, we define σ(i) = Sum of all positive divisors ofi.For example: all positive divisors of 60 = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 10, 12, 15, 20, 30, 60}So σ(60) = 1 + 2 + 3 + 4 + 5 + 6 + 10 + 12 + 15 + 20 + 30 + 60 = 168Now for the task: given an integernfind smallest integerisuch that σ(i) =n.InputThe first line is an integerT(1 ≤T≤ 100,000), denoting the number of test cases. Then, T test cases follow.For each test case, there is an integern(1 ≤n≤ 100,000,000) written in one line. (One integer per line.)OutputFor each test case, output the smallest inverse sum of divisors ofn. ifndoesn't have inverse, output -1.ExampleInput:5
1
16
40
60
168Output:1
-1
27
24
60Time Limit ≈ 2.5*(My Program Top Speed)See also:Another problem added by Tjandra Satria Gunawan
